metadata.titleEn: Long term vegetation index dataset of the Yellow River upstream – Spot vegetation (1998-2011)
metadata.description:
I. Overview
The long-term sequence China Vegetation Index dataset is mainly for the normalized vegetation index (NDVI), based on four bands synthesized every 10 days from 1 April 1998 to 31 December 2011 with a spatial resolution of 1 km. Spectral reflectance and 10-day maximized NDVI dataset.
Ⅱ. Data processing description
The VEGETATION sensor was launched by SPOT-4 in March 1998, and has received SP0T VGT data for global vegetation coverage observation since April 1998. It has a very complete and efficient image ground processing mechanism system. The VEGETATION data is mainly received by the Kiruna ground station in Sweden. The image quality monitoring center in Toulouse, France is responsible for image quality and provides related parameters (such as calibration coefficients). Finally, the image processing and archiving center of VITO Institute in Belgium Global VEGETATION data archiving and user orders. Among them, VGT-P (prototype) data products mainly provide scientific researchers with high-quality physical quantity prototype data in order to facilitate their research and development of algorithms and application models. The data undergoes strict systematic error correction and resampling into a longitude and latitude network projection, the pixel resolution is lkm, and the pixel brightness value is the reflectivity of the ground features on the top layer of the atmosphere. In addition to providing four bands of raw data, relevant auxiliary parameters such as atmospheric conditions, system information (solar zenith angle, azimuth, field of view, and reception time) and terrain data are also provided according to user needs. VGT-S (synthesis) products provide atmospheric-corrected surface reflectance data, and use multi-band synthesis techniques to obtain a normalized vegetation index (w) data set with lkm resolution. VGI-S products include the spectral reflectance and NDVI data set (s1) of four bands synthesized daily, the spectral reflectance of four bands synthesized every 10 days, and the maximum NDVI data set (S10) every 10 days to reduce cloud and The impact of BRDF, while S10 was also resampled into 4km resolution (S10.4) and 8km resolution (S10.8) datasets. VGT-S products are widely used for their high time resolution. This data set contains the spectral reflectance of four bands synthesized every 10 days and the 10-day maximized NDVI data set (S10). The pre-processing of SPOT source data includes atmospheric correction, radiation correction, and geometric correction. NDVI data with a maximum of 10 days of synthesis is generated, and the values ​​of -1 to -0.1 are set to -0.1, and then formula
YDN = (JNDVI +0.1) /0.004
Convert to a YDN value from 0 to 250.
Ⅲ. Data content description
The long-term sequence China Vegetation Index dataset is mainly for the normalized vegetation index (NDVI), based on four bands synthesized every 10 days from 1 April 1998 to 31 December 2011 with a spatial resolution of 1 km. Spectral reflectance and 10-day maximized NDVI dataset. The SPOT-VEGETATION-NDVI data set contains .zip compressed files with time resolution from April 1, 1998 to December 31, 2011. After decompression, it is an ESRI-GRID file with a scene every 10 days. The SPO-VEGETATION-NDVI data set naming rules are: v-yymmdd, where v is the abbreviation of vegetation, yymmdd represents the date of the file, and is the main identifier that distinguishes other files.
Ⅳ. Data usage description
An important feature of the Vegetation Index product is that it can be converted into leaf crown biophysical parameters. Vegetation index (VI) also plays an "intermediate variable" in the acquisition of vegetation biophysical parameters (such as foliar index LAI, green shade, fAPAR, etc.). The relationship between vegetation indices and vegetation biophysical parameters is currently being studied using globally representative ground, aircraft and satellite observation datasets. These data can be used to evaluate the performance of the VI algorithm before satellite launch, and also provide the conversion coefficient between the vegetation index product and the biophysical characteristics of the leaf crown. The use of biophysical data is part of the Vegetation Index Verification Program. Vegetation index products will play a major role in several Earth Observation System (EOS) studies and are also part of global and regional biosphere model products in recent years.

Quantification.Question: How many days are covered in a dataset focusing on 10-day composite spectral reflectance and NDVI data from 1998 to 2011?

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of '归一化植被指数（NDVI）' in the context of vegetation data collection?
Definition.Answer: 归一化植被指数（NDVI） is a normalized difference vegetation index used to quantify vegetation by measuring the difference between near-infrared (which vegetation strongly reflects) and red light (which vegetation absorbs). In vegetation data collection, it serves as an important parameter for assessing vegetation health, density, and dynamics over time, and it is used as an intermediate variable in deriving biophysical parameters such as leaf area index (LAI) and photosynthetically active radiation (fAPAR).

Comparison.Question: How do the data processing techniques used in the creation of a long-term vegetation index dataset compare to those used in atmospheric correction and radiometric calibration in similar datasets?
Comparison.Answer: The data processing techniques for creating a long-term vegetation index dataset include atmospheric correction, radiometric correction, and geometric correction to produce a 10-day maximum composite NDVI dataset. These techniques are similar to those used in atmospheric correction and radiometric calibration in other datasets, where the goal is to ensure the data accurately reflects real-world conditions by removing atmospheric and instrument-related noise. Additionally, the dataset is resampled to a 1km resolution and includes auxiliary parameters such as atmospheric conditions and system information.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying rules or methodologies might be inferred from the use of spectral reflectance and NDVI data synthesized every 10 days for vegetation monitoring?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of spectral reflectance and NDVI data synthesized every 10 days for vegetation monitoring suggests a methodology focused on reducing noise from transient atmospheric conditions like clouds and minimizing bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF) effects. This approach allows for a more consistent and reliable observation of vegetation indices over time. The synthesis process, which includes atmospheric and geometric corrections, exemplifies the rigorous preprocessing needed to ensure accurate temporal tracking of vegetation changes. Additionally, the conversion of indices to biophysical parameters implies an underlying rule of utilizing intermediate variables to infer ecological characteristics such as leaf area index and photosynthesis efficiency.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a long-term normalized vegetation index dataset with 10-day composite NDVI data on the accuracy and reliability of vegetation-related biophysical parameter studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a long-term normalized vegetation index dataset with 10-day composite NDVI data allows for the reduction of cloud and BRDF effects, which enhances the accuracy and reliability of studies focused on vegetation-related biophysical parameters. The dataset's high temporal resolution provides a detailed time series of vegetation changes, offering a significant advantage in studying the relationships between vegetation indices and biophysical parameters such as leaf area index (LAI), green cover, and photosynthetically active radiation absorption (fAPAR). Additionally, the dataset's systematic error corrections and atmospheric corrections contribute to the robustness of these studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting a long-term vegetation index dataset based on SPOT-VEGETATION data from 1998 to 2011?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include providing high-quality vegetation index data for research purposes, facilitating the development of algorithms and application models, and serving as a crucial intermediary variable for obtaining vegetation biophysical parameters. This dataset aims to enhance the understanding of the relationship between vegetation indices and biophysical parameters like LAI, green cover, and fAPAR, and to support the evaluation of VI algorithm performance before satellite launches. Furthermore, it plays a significant role in global and regional biosphere modeling and contributes to several Earth Observation System (EOS) studies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in preprocessing satellite-based NDVI datasets to ensure accuracy and usability in vegetation studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The preprocessing of satellite-based NDVI datasets involves several key steps to ensure accuracy and usability. These include atmospheric correction, radiometric correction, and geometric correction. The datasets are corrected for systematic errors and resampled to a geographic projection with a pixel resolution of 1km. The NDVI data is synthesized every 10 days to maximize reflectance and reduce the influence of clouds and BRDF (Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function) effects. Additionally, values are converted using a specific formula to scale them appropriately.
